And so the matter stands at present—if the Indians agree amongst themselves, the treaty will be opened to-morrow; otherwise the Governor will strike camp and return to Fort Garry.

Divisions and local jealonsies have taken possession of the Indian mind. The diiiiculties are the inability of the Indians to select a high or principal chief from amongst themselves, and as to the matter and extent of the demands to be made.

It is many years since these people had a general council, and in the interval many head men have died, while others have grown to man’s estate, and feel ambitious to take part in the proceedings. But the ﬂat has gone forth, that unless a con- clusion is arrived at tc-morrow negotiations will be broken off for this year.

BOUNDARIES OF THE LANDS TO BE CEDED.

Beginning at the North~West Angle eastward, taking in all the Lake of the Woods, including W'hite Fish Bay, Rat Por- tage and north to White Dog in English River; up English River to Lake Sen], and then south-east to Lake Nepigon; west- ward to Rainy River and down it to Lake of the \Vocds, and up nearly to Lac des Mille Lacs ; then beginning at the 49th parallel to White Mouth River, thence down it to the north, along the eastern boundary of the land ceded in 1871, embrac- ing 55,000 square miles. '

In the neighborhood of Lao des mille Lacs and Shebandowan are several bands, who have sent word that they cannot come as far as this point, but will accept the terms made at this treaty and ratify it with any one commissioner who will go there to meet them.
